citations.narrative:
On February 11, 2024, during an unscheduled otter encounter at the facility, a guest was bitten on the right cheek by
Opal, the female otter. According to the facility, the incident occurred when one of the employees was not following the
facility’s handling protocols and was holding Opal to close to one of the guests. The otter then launched and bit the guest
in the right cheek and resulted in wounds that broke the skin.
Inadequate handling or control of animals during public interactions can lead to injury of the public and the animals.
Additionally, animals involved in injuring the public could be at risk of euthanasia.
The facility must ensure that animals are handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals and
the public during exhibition and/or encounters.
To be corrected from this day forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
REBECCA NANNEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On February 11, 2024, during an unscheduled otter encounter at the facility, a guest was bitten on the right cheek by 
Opal, the female otter. According to the facility, the incident occurred when one of the employees was not following the 
facility’s handling protocols and was holding Opal to close to one of the guests. The otter then launched and bit the guest 
in the right cheek and resulted in wounds that broke the skin.  
 Inadequate handling or control of animals during public interactions can lead to injury of the public and the animals. 
Additionally, animals involved in injuring the public could be at risk of euthanasia.  
The facility must ensure that animals are handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals and 
the public during exhibition and/or encounters. 
 
To be corrected from this day forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
REBECCA NANNEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: CONGO AFRICAN GREY PARROT / GRAY PARROT
